bibl.title: Letter from Henry Rose Carter to Laura Armistead Carter, July 23, 1922

div1.p: Carter describes his trip to South Carolina, but refuses to make anymore long journeys. He discusses financial affairs and family issues.

div1.head: Letter from Henry Rose Carter to Laura Armistead Carter, July 23, 1922
div1.opener:
What do you hear of the Gorgas Memorial
School of P. H. at Tuscaloosa?
Wateree S. C.
July 23d/22
My Dearest Daughter:
div1.p:
I left Marion Wednesday mor-
ning at 5.25 A. M. & greached Camden that
afternoon. It was raining & had been
raining all the week. There was one
visit place that it was desireable to visit -
very desireable - but it was practically im-
possible to reach- It was about 15 miles
from Camden - but the road was reported as
impossible. It is 7 miles from this place-
Wateree - but across the river. I went
there last year - by launch - but that is
now out of commission. It was proposed
to go around about way by Auto, - but
this involved a ride of 67 miles each
way - & I would not undertake it.

It was agreed that I would let it go & re-
turn to Washington. & come back soon to
be at Camden next Wednesdayor Th Tuesday night- This
would give me. Friday to Monday inclusive
2
i e. 2 1/2 working days, & I got ready to go. off
Thursday morning!- Saturday is a 1/2 day at the
Library - 9-12.

Thinking over it I changed my mind, & came
here instead - to await a possible change
of weather. It has not come until today & this is too late.- However I
a find that I can get to within 13 miles of my
destination by rail & a machine will
meet me there & I will do this Tuesday
& get to Camden Tuesday evening.

I stayed on my own mottion motion - so am
only going to charge what I would have done
had I returned to Washington- I will get
however $350. on this trip however & if the
case lasts over Wednesday- I think it will last
into Thursday - $50.00 more.

I was hurt - Kink - by a long automobile
ride I took at Marion & was quite sick.on Tuesday & was
feeling quite badly - from Friday night to
Saturday night - 24 hours about, It seems
to be over now - but I it was on this account
that I declined the long ride, It was a mis-
understanding at Marion- We went down
My hip is doing very well - as well as, or better
than, it was in Washington.
3
by boat - about 30 miles - took a short - 10 mile-
Auto trip & the boat was to have met us but
did not. I explained that I was willing
to make the AugustSeptember survey - about 3 days
maybe 4- by boat but that I would not
take any more long land trips. The same
here. They want me in September, - but I
doubt if I will, attend - not unless they get
another boat.

I have written my answer to Wickliffe
Rose's letter & it was rather a job. I taketook
practically all Friday to get it done &
yesterday afternoon to finish it. How-
ever, I will b it is done, & I will have it ty-
ped when I get a chance. It would have
taken a day, of the 2 1/2 days, in had I gone
on to Washington

When I go back my plan is to go by
the Southern to Amherst. Change there
to the local train for New Glasgow. Don't
exactly know how the trains nun run
4
but last year the through train got to
Amherst & stopped there about 5 P. M. & the
local came by early next morning - the
same I got from Lynchburg. At any rate I
can make Lynchburg & take the local
from that place - only one has to go about
4 miles across town & it is nuisance
& then an auto to the station next morning.

I rec'd your letter written anon the train &
I judge that I will get another one Tues-
day - at Camden, I wrote you from Marion,
a short letter. Have written to Fannie
Claiborne to forward my letter mail to
Charlotte - Care Southern Power Co & when
I get to Camden will advise be to hold
it. I think your next letter had best be
addressed to me at New Glasgow, - but if
there be any emergency - to Camden
Care Mr de Loach - Att. at Law, I expect
5
to leave Camden Thurday evening - but
may do so- Thursday morning: or even possi-
bly Wednesday morningnight. The trial on the other
hand may hold me into Friday- I think not,
however

How is Henry & how is he doing? If
he has to raise money from his Capital
I judge he can do so most advantageous-
ly from his Liberty bonds- They are at
par. yeild 4 1/4% & I presume he does not
have to pay much income tax - at least
no excess tax - I wish he had. I will
make enough on this trip & what I have a-
greed to do at Marion - i.e., go at least as a
witness - to cover the $400. I must re-
turn to Hayne in the fall. Hope I will
have $100. over to cover our extra tax on
intangibles laid on this year.

I am rather anxious to get back to Va. To rest
a while- I am resting now by the way &
wish I had sent for the S. E. Post & Cosmopolitan
yesterday. Then to get at my History: & to be rea-
dy to meet Hanson, in New York
6
I don't think he will possibly be in until a-
bout tothe & & 12-15 of August, Walcott will proba-
bly want to see me - if he comes about that time

In wrote to Rose from Washington: Ackn
Acknowledging the receipt of his letter of July
12 - & telling him I would answer as soon as
I could. g I gave him the S. P. Co- as my tem-
porary address - & will give New Glasgow
when I leave for that place.

I could have utilized the 2 1/2 days in
Washington to great advantage at the
S. G' l's library- I want to finish Chis-
holm's book - about a day - & read Pym's &
Andanard's.- I have Chisholm wrong. He
counted the Bulam fever as made de no-
vo - not out of malaria - aboard ship. Under
ordinary conditions- Typhus would have
been produced; under tropical ones- this
“nova peste” resulted - very like Typhus
not at all like the y. f. of the West Indies
which was “frankly paludal” & “never con-
7
contagious”,- A. hybrid fever was formed
with y. f. however - which now becamewas com-
municable. That is the y. f. of the West Indies
- by which he meant malarial fever - had
never been contagious. This new fever - gen-
erated, by crowlding crowding & lack of ven-
tilation aboard the. Hankey - conditions w'h in
cold climates generated Typhhus - was frankly
contagious. & after being a year in the Little
Antilles - “took on the off much of the as-
pect of y. f.” but was transmissible. ii
Evidently there was no y. f. in the Antilles
at the time, & it was what was so called, y. f
was malaria: & y. f. was reintroduced
from Africa! It is very interesting
especially the point of view - of an educa-
ted close observer who had not the key to
the problem: I did not finish the book
& must do so.

It has not been hot here &, as you know, I
have been doing nothing since last Tues-
day-: so - except for the time my kink was.
bothering me
8
I have been comfortable enough-

There won't be much cotton in this coun-
try what with the rains & the cold & the
boll - weevil.

Write me all about yourself - you have
been in Birmingham 8 days today-
Give my love to Coleman Morris &
Mrs Morris - to Dr & Mrs Noland & to the
Walshes.- & naturally to Henry tofor whom
this letter is meant as much as
for yourself.
div1.closer:
Very Truly
Your loving father H. R. Carter Ask Noland & Dr Morris - if they know
anything of my old friends the
Fla. Power Co- Mr for whose pool
Lock #12: Coosa River - LePrince: & I
worked on in 1915. Mr Martin - then At-
torney & now Vice President. I regarded
very highly - an entirely honorable man
C
